title: How I survive Christmas as a neurodivergent adult
subtitle: Christmas breaks my routine, overloads my senses, and reactivates old stuff I thought I’d dealt with.
author: Rhys Morgan
content_html:
Christmas breaks my routine, overloads my senses, and reactivates old stuff I thought I’d dealt with. This is how I get through it without burning out.

Christmas is not one day for me.
It’s weeks of noise, interruptions, and expectations I didn’t agree to.

For a long time, I told myself I’d “cope better this year”.
I never did.

What helped wasn’t trying harder.
It was preparing honestly.

I stopped pretending Christmas would feel calm.
And started planning like it wouldn’t.

That one shift changed everything.

I expect my routine to break.
I expect my nervous system to be jumpy.
I expect old family dynamics to make a surprise appearance.

Not because I’m negative.
Because I’m realistic.

So I decide things early.
How long I’m staying.
What I’m skipping.
When I’m leaving.

I don’t make those choices in the moment.
I make them while my brain is still on my side.

On the day itself, I keep it simple.

I eat before hunger turns into irritation.
I take breaks before I’m overwhelmed.
I step outside without explaining myself.
I leave early without apologising.

I don’t push through discomfort to be polite.
Politeness is expensive.

And when I do get triggered — because I do —
I don’t argue with my nervous system.

I pause.
I ground.
I don’t pile shame on top of stress.

Then, when it’s over, I rest.
On purpose.

No replaying conversations.
No big decisions.
No self-interrogation.

Recovery is part of Christmas too.

I don’t aim to enjoy every moment.
I aim to survive it intact.

If Christmas feels like this for you too, I’ve put everything I use into a short, free Google Doc.

No hype.
No fixing.
Just what helps.

You’ll find the free Christmas survival doc linked below.

And if nothing else, let this be enough:

You’re not doing Christmas wrong.
You’re just doing it with a nervous system that notices everything.

That’s how I prepare for two weeks of overstimulation, lack of routine, and too many triggers.
Christmas.

How I survive Christmas as a neurodivergent adult
